Topic: Draw a habitat and the different living things in each
CAN: The student can draw a basic representation of a specific habitat with an obvious land or water environment, such as a simple forest or pond scene.
The student can include some living things found in the habitat, like basic plant shapes (trees, flowers) and simple animal shapes (squirrels, fish).
The student may attempt to show how plants and animals are organized in the habitat, although the organization may not be fully accurate or detailed.
CANNOT: The student cannot consistently demonstrate understanding of the diversity of living things, potentially including a limited variety of plants and animals or omitting some entirely (e.g., only showing one type of tree and one type of animal).

The student might not label or identify patterns in the natural world accurately, possibly not distinguishing clear similarities and differences between different habitats or missing labels entirely (*student may think all natural environments are similar without clear differences*).
